bibl.note: This is a letter dated June 13, 1839 from James King to his son Henry King. James King gives his son several directions for looking after the plantation, and requests that every thing be well tended to.

address.addrLine: Mr Henry A.J. King Rural Rest, Murfreesboro Rutherford County Tene.

opener.add: We all join in love and respects to you all your beloved father Ja M King

div1.p: I presume you have understood the progress of our journey to Tuskaloosa by your uncle Gan n away-

We arrived at Tuskaloosa 31st May- We ware very affectionately recd by all our friends they are generally well. Your Cousin Ann is in better health than she has been But does not enjoy very good health, they all made special enquires about you especiallly your uncle Thomas and lady, they all speak highly of your civil and morral deportment, and feel very solicituous for your prosperity- Your uncle Tom son and daughter are going to school, little Dick is going but pore little fellow cant learn, he is very much attached to us - Mr Byrd was with us several days he is going to the university, to school, and has to study very hard, he made considerably enquirery about you, and abut your progress at school-

Mr Ellis opposes Mr Crab for congress, it is thought he will be elected-. I think very highly of Mr Ellis, he is very much of a gentleman- After spending quite an agreeably weeak at Tuskaloosa we left for moringo on the 6th of June
by the way of Cousin Loucrese Bakers, in Green county near Clinton, we met them all in fine health and was much rejoiced to see us we ware all well till saturday the 8th that evening your mother was taken with a violent headake, ( I suspect by eating Wortleberries) I gave her labelia and soon relieved her- whilst here I herd from Coln Robert Smith at clinton at the raises, I understood he wone two raises thier one 2 mile & repeat, distanced the field the first heat, the other best 3 in 5, run four heats, was very clost contested, run the saim horse both raises he was a Leviathan, not knowing Coln smith was their till saturday evening I went there on to clinton on sunday morning but he was gaun I understand he wone numbers of rases, I understood he had sold or was likely to sell the horse that run for $2500 - on monday the 10th we set out for Coln H Kings arrived their the 12t, Your cousin Penelope Carvonis went with us - We found no wone at home but your Cousin Henry, Your Cousin Helen had gaun to cahauba on a visit I expect her here tomorrow Your Cousin Henry's suninlaw Croa c hran that married Lucrettea, they are here, we are very well entertained and enjoy, our selves very well Your Mother and the rest of us are all enjoying the very best of health, we will leave here by the 20th of this month for Tuskaloosa, we, shall leave
their about the 25th for your cousin Tom Moore as Ten near Clays-ville or Ten. R- I shall aim to get home between the 15 & 20th of July- when you receive this write to me at Hazlegreen I am not certain any of our friends will return with us or not - crops of all sorts are excidingly fine here , cotton are are bluming finely, and corn in ro a stingyears I have seen the roasnyeas roastingyears corn purfectly dry at Kings, and he has planted some corn that has grown this year, It is very dry and hot hear at present, and are wanting rain. Bacon are offerring here at 12 1/2 cts; tell your uncle Gannaway to sell mine -

Henry you and Mr Ship. I have great reliance in your care and attention about the domestic affaires of the house as well as that of the plantation, and wish every thing to be snugly attended to, I want my year old and suckling coalts to be well attended to, my wheat and other small grain to be well attended to, my crop I shall expect to fine in good order I want you to stay generally about home, write to me about my crop, I have'nt herd any thing from home since left, sho this letter to your Ant Jane cousin Martha, your Grandmother and you uncles as I cant rite to them all- Your Grandmother mother & sister enjoyes themselves very well, and pleased with travelling, - your mother are wanting to see little mit very much they all, send their love and respects to every body, tell the children all about us, and houdy, to be good children, that we will be at home before long, tell James & Charles to gt fat & grow big.
